title: Will the Republican candidate for president win the party's nomination on the first ballot, at the party's convention in July?
preds:
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus. 
I think Pence will unite the Republican Party and strengthens the Republican ticket.
The "Stop Trump" effort failed to sway the Repub Rules Committee. Relevant CNN article: http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/14/politics/republican-rules-delegates-trump/
The #NeverTrump movement was effectively crushed. Their tactics with the Rules Committee failed.
Staying at 100% because NeverTrumpers have failed every attempt they have tried this far proving their complete incompetence

Depends on how the Rules Committee goes regarding "unbinding" Trump delegates from being required to vote for Trump. There still seems to be some energy in the "Never Trump" crowd. This July 14 Washington Post article provides some insight: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/07/13/your-definitive-guide-to-the-rnc-rules-committee-meeting/ I'm raising my probability estimate Trump will win on first ballot. Trump's selection of Pence for VP might have helped Trump among conservatives.
Plan A won't work. Pence is acceptable to many republicans (Trump is smart, I'll give him that.)

Never thought I'd ever ask this but...
Does anyone know of any links where I might be able to watch live commentary of the convention and the cordoned off protest area?
Pence is the insider to balance the ticket.  Never Trump crowd might have had some votes, but reports are, they do not have a candidate.

Slate: "After 10 or so hours of debate over occasionally interesting amendments, the RNC rules committee signed off for the night on Thursday by tanking the big one: the rule, proposed by Colorado delegate Kendal Unruh, that would unbind delegates from their first ballot obligations and allow them to vote their conscience. Never-Trumpers will continue to argue, perhaps forever, that they still have some snazzy new trick up their sleeve for snatching the nomination from Trump. But they don’t. It’s over."

Un-binding of delegates wasn't likely ever a realistic idea. I watched an hour of the RNC Rules Committee meeting last night, it was clear only a small fringe of the committee actually took un-binding seriously. Trump people and the party chair are given credit for lobbying against it. They probably didn't need to bother.
The anti-Trump forces seem to have thrown in the towel. Staying away from 100% since everything this year has been wacky.
Near certainty now after rules votes
Pence scuppered that with his sincere Christian values. That and on going terror attacks which give force to trump's rhetoric
RNC Rules Committee offering no surprises for Trump.
trump voters who can't vote trump, won't vote hillary. They would likely vote another republican - assuming all goes according to Kendall Unruh's plan
GOP can change its own rules to unbind delegates.

Federal Court rules that Virginia (a "state") cannot require a delegate to vote for a specific candidate, but the political party, through its party/ convention rules, can.  
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2016/07/11/federal-court-rules-virginia-cant-force-its-gop-convention-delegates-to-vote-for-trump/
Barring a pre-convention surprise, there is little reason to think Trump won't win on the first ballot.
I have no special information on this topic, but:

Va delegation is free to vote for whomever now.  Federal judge rules Trump delegate can oppose Trump, bars Virginia from enforcing its law to bind delegates. I suspect there will be other states, or maybe even a rules committee vote to allow all open, latter a wild card. I still think Trump could win an open convention. Definitely think he can win without a few delegations, Va included.

Federal Judge Rules for Anti-Trump GOP Delegate (-28)
http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/judge-va-trump-delegate-unbound-voting-him-rnc-n607461
Never trump has lost.  Updating appropriately.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports, PredictIt.com, 538.com, and GJP consensus.
This seems like a sideshow, but I'm inclined to downgrade slightly: http://www.wsj.com/articles/anti-donald-trump-forces-see-convention-coup-as-within-reach-1467839099
As Trump's favourability ratings with voters polled falls it strengthens the republican revolt and his chances get less

GOP Close To Dumping Trump As Coup Plotters Near Votes Needed To Cause Nomination Chaos 
http://www.politicususa.com/2016/07/06/gop-close-dumping-trump-coup-plotters-votes-nomination-chaos.html
Be very hard to diss candidate so favored by their voters. But if they change delegate rules.....

Repub delegates are being encouraged to "vote their conscience and country" instead of voting for Trump. However, many delegates could stick with Trump. Politico article: “Why Trump won’t get dumped in Cleveland” at http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/donald-trump-cleveland-convention-225056 I'm slightly increasing my probability estimate Trump will win on first ballot.
If politics is teaching us anything this year (Boris Johnson not running being just the latest), nothing is 100% anymore, so dropping to 96%.

Down 5% to reflect difficulties Trump has had marshaling establishment support. But, given the lack of plausible alternatives, I see him winning the nomination on the first ballot.  No one else is currently challenging him for the nomination, and who else will the vote go to?
Due to the increasing rebellion against Trump, including by prominent Repub leaders, I'm lowering my estimate of a first-ballot win for Trump. It seems there could be a fight.
Back up 2%.The whole revolt idea was a long shot. Should make interesting theater instead of something boring.

Raising the probability of this - RNC clamping down on rebels
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/27/us/politics/donald-trump-and-rnc-see-common-foe-rogue-delegates.html?_r=0

All points to Trump being the nominee, and I think he will be, the question is if the opposition he is facing within his party will be but a scuffle at the start of the Convention or if it can create enough disruption as to prevent a first ballot Trump vote (some rogue delegates are suing, some are threatening to use a "conscientious objector" rule.
Upping forecast, but still not a sure thing, in my opinion.

There is an anti-Trump movement of sorts. Whether or not it'll make up the numbers on the convention floor is a very different question. Unless this gathers more momentum over the next few days I'll increase my forecast.
http://www.politico.com/story/2016/06/donald-trump-delegate-revolt-224634
The fact that the RNC now supports a Trump nomination means that he is likely to win on the first ballot.
Delegate Revolt, Republican Elite "Vote your conscience."
No change. Updating before resolution date & for participation purposes.
I am backing down here.  His party is in open rebellion.

Wow. I really thought this was a done deal. My reasoning was that party bosses would rather allow Trump to win that somehow tarnish the images of the RNCs policies. Moving the goalposts to get their way after the fact would cause even more desertion from the party because that would mean they couldn't be trusted to uphold the will of the people. However, there's a slight chance that some sort of shenanigans will occur. It won't help in the end, but unbinding delegates may spoil the first ballot.

chatter around delegates being unbound - by changing RNC rules. This might be a thing - not sure if they want to go against huge #'s of voters but recent CNN poll (tinkered?) showed that 48% of republicans now want to vote for someone else.
Trump will win on the first ballot. There is no evidence that any version of the #nevertrump movement has the power to stop him.

I am pretty sure Trump is going to win the nomination (what alternative do the Republicans have), but he is so disliked among the establishment and doing so poorly in the polls that it is possible the convention rules will be changed - unbinding delegates to Trump.  At that point, we have a civil war among Republicans.  What are the odds?  Who knows, but higher than 1 in 100 that I have predicted now.  Going to 1 in 20 (95%).
I guess there's no metaphysical certainty when it comes to what the GOP will or won't do, this unconventional season. I think it's well north of 99% but can no longer bring myself to round up.

There remains any manner of freakishly deranged lunacy when the GOP lights their big bonfire at the convention. However, Trump has a lock on the votes and delegates so he has to be the candidate. The longshot but only reality based alternative is a major front page news factionalization of the GOP at h convention leading a to essentially a new party. this would require party moderates to be activley engaged and planning which seems very unlikely, however a popular moderate could potentially lead a break off from the Trump block. Not sure who could or would pull it off. Someone new to the campaign cycle coming out of the trees with the "rich white guy credibility" and organizational energy to attract a first day block of support. Romney could try but won't because it's s failure guaranteed candidacy intening to build for the long road ahead. Maybe Susan Collins or someone really out there like Martha Stewart or Jon Voight. - it's all an extreme longshot but given the nutty for profit campaign trends it's a possibly to be noted.

A little doubt based on current polling. At least a contested (open) convention has excitement.  A demoralized one is most likely now.
Is there any VP candidate that could make this happy-exciting for them at this point?
Trump has enough pledged delegates to be nominated on the first ballot.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Four in ten GOP insiders seek to deny Trump!
4-in-10 GOP insiders want to derail Trump at the convention
Politico - 2hÂ ago
After a rocky start to his general-election campaign, a sizable number of GOP insiders want the party to change the rules to short-circuit Donald Trump's nomination at the July national convention.
http://goo.gl/Wd7B4v
Earlier low forecasts may have been ahead of the curve.  GOP may, now, start to give public consideration to the options still open for the convention.
They would be wise to not nominate the one who is not wise.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
A good V P pick and Trump deals with the party leaders.
Passage of time &, participation before Q closes!
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Why hasn't this already closed? I know there are addendums and exceptions and whatnot, but if the chances are less than 1% of something not happening, it's functionally a done deal.
Everybody seems to be playing nice so bumping it up to 100
And a gold-plated ballot it will be, too.
Forecast for participation purposes. No change to recent my forecast.
(no change) Just wondering if the Rs will stage manage the voting such that it quickly moves into a "by acclamation" selection of DT? Would assume this would count for a yes.
No nutcase scenarios gonna play out - relax guys this is still a done deal. Though I still believe that a popular third candidate (most likely one from the Republican camp) will run as an independent

NYTimes outlines unlikely scenarios for GOP convention:
---Delgates require the nominee to receive a "supermajority" rather than a "majority".
---Allow any candidate with 1 delegate to be entered into nomination (Cruz, Rubio, Kasich, Jeb!, Carson, plus more), preventing Trupm from obtaining a majority on the first vote.
GOP is behind the presumptive nominee so there is a pretty good chance to get the nomination on first ballot
They have no-one else that I can see
(no change) Perhaps the R Poobahs should make watching "Being There" mandatory before the convention:
Looks like barring a major rules change, Trump will win.

Now that Sen. Cruz and Gov. Kasich have folded their operations, the way appears open for Mr. Trump to claim his prize.  I leave a 1% chance of back-room shennanigans and faithless delegates, which would be fun to watch, but devastating to our electoral process.  Speaker Ryan and Sen. McConnell know that their efforts to hold on to the majorities in Congress depend on the goodwill of Mr. Trump's voters come November.
dam, I forgot about this question
Not giving 100% forecasts anymore when crowd consensus is nearby.
Isn't this done and over with yet? I thought it is!
It seems that Trump has it wrapped up.
Closing the door on this question as well
Since Trump is the only candidate left, it is mathematically impossible for anyone else. 100%.
People are settling into the idea of Trump like they settle into a hot bath. After the initial shock, the water isn't quite so hot.
Cruz and Kasich leave remaining delegates to Trump.

After Indiana, I ran millions of iterations of the remaining delegate possibilities with "winner take all" and proportional. Even without considering Cruz's drop out, Trump lands at the necessary number of delegates in approximately 70% (69.76%) of the cases. I think Cruz's withdrawal makes it far more likely than this suggests, but until we see how the subsequent support flows, this is where I am...

Looked at my forecast again. Trump is on such a role that he now should win Nebraska, which basically gives him 1237+. At that point Kasich should drop out and we have the contest most people were scared of, but at the same time secretly hoping for: Clinton V Trump.
With Cruz out of the race, Trump looks very likely to pick up enough committed delegates before the convention.
Indiana result seals the deal for Trump.

There have been a lot of twists to this election. As things stand now, Kasich can still have a contested convention if he sweeps a bunch of states and one of those states is California (which votes on the last day). If there is a contested convention, it might go to Kasich.
Oh dear. It's over I think. Trump wins.
It's DT's game to lose at this time.
DT will get 1237+ delegates, only possibility of preventing his candidacy is a change in rules. Which could quite possibly shatter the GOP, very very unlikely.
Absent rules change or sudden shift, this seems like a pretty sure thing.
I'd say 100%, but that is insane.  Let's stick with 99%.  Reason?  Cruz quit and Donald won Indiana.  Even if Cruz hadn't quit, Trump was maybe a dozen from 1237.  This contest is settled.
DT has redefined for GOP Taleb's term Antifragile.
I think Trump will get the delegates
With Ted out of contention, this is virtually certain.
Big win for Trump in Indiana, coupled with Cruz suspending his campaign.

Results from Indiana combined with Cruz drop out gives DT the mandate to push the party through on one ballot. If the GOP tried to take away the nod from DT at this point, they would risk seriously fracturing the party.
Trump in one - even Cruz has thrown in the towel.
Sen. Cruz's withdrawal makes a contested convention highly unlikely.
With Cruz gone, caution on this one is not warranted.
Updating for Indiana primary (100% chance of 1195+ and 88% of 1237+) and TC suspending his campaign.
Trump wins Indiana.  Matching my forecast on the nomination winner question:

Recent wins have bolsters Trump's chances of a first ballot win. He is now likely to pick up the Pennsylvania delegates, and it is looking like a win in Indiana. That make even a modest win in California enough to put him over the top, and a strong win in California more likely.
Upgrading Trump based on early Indiana results and strong recent polling in California

The net is closing now on the STOP TRUMP folks.  Trump will probably win all of Indiana's 57 delegates today.  There are two other WTA states left (Montana - 27 delegates and S. Dakota - 29 delegates) where he will likely be favored.   The rest of the primaries are proportional.  If Trump wins Indiana today, he will need just 184 more delegates of the 397 remaining (46%).   Trump leads in polling in nearly all of these remaining states.  He's tied with Cruz in New Mexico.  Polls can sometimes be wrong, but the proportional system is such that they would have to be wildly wrong for Trump not to get 1237 delegates for the first ballot.
Moving up, as Trump does better.
Updating this to bring it in line with my forecast on Trump nomination.
Trump has a large lead in Indiana. Was Cruz' last stand
worried about the guy enough to go against the wishes of voters?
Yes. Trump will have enough delegates to get the nomination on the first ballot, when you consider unbound delegates who will probably vote for him.

The "never Trump" faction is determined to block his nomination. Trump is seen as destructive to the nation and party.
But Cruz is an even more divisive candidate who has been antagonistic to the Republican establishment, with whom he is now seeking to curry favor.
Kasich is positioned as the trustworthy and rational Republican but has little enthusiastic support. Some view his collaboration with Cruz as admitting that he is not seeking the Presidency, only to block Trump, leaving the nomination to Trump.
The path depends on which is seem as less destructive: (a) thwarting the will of voters, possibly losing Republican voters for years to come, in order to block a dangerous demagogue or (b) nominate Trump, accept that both parties will need to realign in coming years, knowing that Clinton is the likely ultimate victor, and hoping, in the event of a Trump presidency, that he is the pragmatic deal-maker that he claims to be.

According to the poll numbers, considering the fairly consistent polls over the past month on Trump's support, and all of the combinations of delegates from the remaining states, by my models, trump gets to 1,237  delegates only 52% of the time. No other candidate can get there, and if Trump doesn't make it to the magic number, there will likely be a brokered convention

Affirming prior. I think Cruz is on track to lose the states he has to win (IN and CA), and that DT will hit 1,237. I also think that a lot of mainstream Republicans have already written off their party's chances in 2016 and would rather see DT get the nomination and then be soundly defeated rather than go through a nasty floor fight only to see Ted Cruz be soundly defeated and still have DT making a ruckus form outside the tent.
Moving Trump chances of earning 1237+ to 48% and 1195+ to 88% based on all the recent polls on the Indiana primary.
Fear of popular revolt will keep GOP shenanigans in check.
Trump has the required number of delegates

Along with picking Donald Trump to win the nomination, I predict that it is extremely likely that he will win on the first ballot, before there is any chance to "correct" the voting of the Republican primary voters and caucus-goers.
Trump wins Indiana & California and gets to 1237
Trump wins IN and has good CA result. That's all she wrote!

Increasing my forecast significantly (50->80) due to the increased forecast for DT getting 1237+. He can get above those even without CA. So if he can pick up CA I think he will get 1237+ and therefore be the nominee on the first ballot.
(Also posted here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/222506, since it's relevant to both questions)

No change.
Information:
No change: Info:

Tedly Cruzorina do not look like winning even Indiana,  Neither they nor John the Bland can stop the steamroller.  Seek a good vantage point from which to which the Republican Party sink beneath the waves, there to remain for probably ten years. If they lose enough state legislatures it will be longer, since there is a reapportionment coming up after the '20 census.
Apparently Cruz is even less popular than Trump, so Trump will win the nomination on the first ballot.
Some chance, but I think not large, that Tedly Cruzorina will win Indiana, but it won't matter.  Unless something very odd happens in California, it's Hair Boy in one.

Trump now has 996 delegates. There are 371 at stake between now and the California primary (CA has 172). There are 131 delegates left at the 4 remaining primaries thereafter. That's a total of 502 delegates available to win before the Convention. If the actual trend in favor of Trump continues, and all is pointing in that direction, he is most likely to get at least 60% of those delegates. More than enough to claim the nomination by delegate count before the Convention.

“Lucifer in the flesh,” the former Speaker said. “I have Democrat friends and Republican friends. I get along with almost everyone, but I have never worked with a more miserable son of a bitch in my life.”http://www.stanforddaily.com/2016/04/28/john-boehner-talks-election-time-in-office/

Updating, as polls indicate Trump is performing better than expected in Indiana.  If he can pull majority delegates in both Indiana and California, I have a hard time seeing him not getting the 30 or 40 uncommitted delegates he probably needs to win on the first nomination.  Indiana I think still favors Cruz at this point, although slightly, and California is no sure thing.
There is no chance he will clinch before California, and he will need to do quite well there.  However, California Republicans are natural-born Trumpeters.
Bumped up DT chances of winning first ballot if he has 1195+ votes from 83% to 86%. The unbounded Pennsylvania delegates, seem to be a little more bounded than I had forecast

Trump needs less than half of remaining delegates  to get to 1,236, which seems very doable based on his performance so far. Even without this he could still win on first ballot by picking up unbound delegates. For example, in Pennsylvania he could pick up 30-40 unbound delegates.

My base case is that this not happening is extremely low as mathematically Trump should win ahead of the convention as the unanimous leader. He needs to win exactly 250 out of 583 available delegates as per Google's figures, while he is roughly clocking 49-50% of vote share, which is significantly higher than the required number. To be revised closer to date

My base case is that this happening is extremely low as mathematically Trump should win ahead of the convention as the unanimous leader. He needs to win exactly 250 out of 583 available delegates as per Google's figures, while he is roughly clocking 49-50% of vote share, which is significantly higher than the required number. To be revised closer to date
Up 10%. Hope I don't have to talk to the cockroaches in 2017.

Trump will get it easily. 
Others will cry foul. The Republican Party has a better chance at presidency with Trump, than with Cruz.
Even if Cruz and Kasich team up. 
Delegates banked by Rubio will split towards Trump. Like, Virginia, Georgia, Oklahoma, North Carolina, Massachusetts.

I've just listened to a bit of Trump's latest speech in Indiana. Honestly, if he wins on the first ballot, then I'll have to revise my ideas about human nature. Not that I can't understand his appeal. I can. I just find it hard to believe that he can appeal to enough people to get to a 50% delegate count on the first ballot (note: I'm taking into account that he can get to 50% of the delegates even though he doesn't have 50% of the vote).
electoral map RCP polling. Still  not buying that coffee.

After DT's performance on Tuesday, his projected delegate count is just short of 1,237. Given exit poll evidence of his support with uncommitted delegates in Pennsylvania, it seems highly likely he could pull their support in July and get through on one ballot if he is only short 40-50 delegates.

I know from experience that the RNC will change or break whatever rule they need to in order to get the outcome they want.  When they were changing the rules in 2012 they had on the teleprompter, "and the ayes have it" and the acting chairman declared that even though it wasn't clear, and they ignored calls for division.  They sent the Maine delegation home and replaced them.  They changed Nevada's vote because they didn't think it was correct.  They will find ways to disqualify Trump delegates, disqualify their votes, or get those slots filled with people who are really anti-Trump.
Changing because Trump has managed 50% popular support for the first time. This is ominous for the remaining candidates, who will need many rabbits to stand a chance.
Trump will have about 130 extra delegates provided he wins Indiana.
I should keep this slightly below the Trump win percentage answer.
Moving up.  Ted Cruz picking Carly as VP smells desperate to me.
I didn't go up enough earlier today.
Up 5%. How could so many of us possibly be wrong?

Mr. Trump's better than expected showing last night moved his mean expected delegate count from 1,191 to 1,200[a]. Quoth Nate Silver: "Based on provisional results,1 it looks as though Trump will sweep every pledged delegate in Maryland (as a result of winning every congressional district), Connecticut (as a result of winning every congressional district and getting more than 50 percent of the vote statewide), Pennsylvania (where statewide delegates are awarded winner-take-all) and Delaware (ditto), along with 11 of 19 delegates in Rhode Island (which is highly proportional). Combined with the New York results,2 that gives Trump 200 delegates since we issued the path-to-1,237 projections, five delegates ahead of his original targets"[b].
Making big shift based on recent results by Trump.

According to 538 Trump gets at least 35 of the unbound delegates in PA. If I adjust my delegate math spreadsheet to produce that number, and leave other unbound delegates as 20% likely to go over to Trump (which now seems like a serious lowball) he is ~100% likely to get at least 53 unbound delegates, and 88% likely to get 60.
Raising, based on last night's wins. Still a way to go before DT clinches though, and if he doesn't come to the convention with a majority of delegates, I think there will be a floor fight.
Raising to 65% because of 4/26 primary results.

The average suberban and country-bumpkin/red-neck republicans are tired of losing and are therefore siding with the front-runner in order to lay claim to any kind of victory, even just a primary victory.
California should do it for The Great and Powerful Oz.  My Gruesome Old Party will now go comatose for probably ten years, maybe longer.

If Donald doesn't make it on the first round, I don't think he has much of a chance afterward. Ted has worked the delegate system better than Donald, and things will tend to go downhill for Trump after the first round.
Trump is on schedule to get all or nearly all the delegates he needs to clinch it.
Even Nate Silver (live blog) had to admit "Trump is killing it w/ evangelicals". Not a big group but, Cruz getting bumpbed by DT in Penn, Conn, &,Del, & Maryland had to hurt Cruz a little bit!
seems that Trump is actually ahead of expectations...

Underestimated Trump again, although not by much this time so only have tweaks to make. I am bumping up Trump to 66% 1195+ (giving him more delegates especially in Oregon and New Mexico) but don't think this changes much in terms of 1237+. Yes he will now end up with more delegates than forecast but without Indiana, I just don't see it (28%). Also you would have thought now that if anything Kasich and Cruz will push their alliance more aggressively to stop Trump in Indiana.....although low voting among evangelicals for Cruz yesterday is a concern to my forecast, need more polls....
all over bar the shouting now.
Trump halved his delegate deficiency, thus I am halving my doubts.  87 it is. There is still the posibility that the party will go insane, thus no higher.

The delegate counts after Today's primaries: https://g.co/kgs/ne4WO
Input into 538's Trump-calculator http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/can-you-get-trump-to-1237/
Coupled with the fact that Trump did well with Pennsylvania's unbound delegates puts him real close to 1237, and this is not even counting unbound delegates that he may convince to vote for him...
Up 10% on 26 Apr results. Also, either the RNC has capitulated or isn't leaking their master plan for a clean sweep.
Trump only needs 48% to clinch it outright assuming nobody more drops out
Trump up. More solid too after a near death experience.
Updating in light of tonight's primaries and current polling.

Four months ago I thought Trump would do well enough to stop anyone else from getting to 1237 on the first ballot. I didn't think he'd have a chance of getting there on the first ballot himself. Now it's clear that a first ballot win for Trump has become quite a likely outcome; and I need to overcompensate for the length of time I've been predicting it wouldn't happen.

The more one reads about the Cruzich deal, the less impressive it seems.  They aren't even urging their supporters to vote for the other guy, they're just saying they won't try in those states.  Whoever set this up may not be dumber than the proverbial box of rocks, but there is no evidence that they are smarter.  Too stupid, too late.

according to 538 and the prediction markets, about 70% chance of Trump getting enough delegates - and a single vote in the face of the fact there is no viable alternative candidate would result in a powerful positive message for the party

Significant change in estimate;  given the cooperative electoral (relative to state primaries) strategy employed by the Cruz and Kasich campaigns, there is some possibility that it could increase the changes for a contested convention.  There are however no guarantees that this strategy could prevent Trump from gaining the magic number;  however, it is possible that it could slow him down if he does not gain the majority of delegates in the states where Cruz and Kasich will employ their cooperative strategy.   Given other factors in play along with other political forces and Trump's campaign response to the situation, it is difficult to estimate the likelihood of the outcome for this IFP.  Until we see the delegate results tomorrow and how these outcome affect all candidates, it still is too early to tell.

Member of the rules committee states that even with 1237 delegates Trump is not certain to be the nominee.  Past experience tells us the establishment will change whatever rules they need to in order to get what they want.
http://dailypoliticsusa.com/breaking-rnc-says-will-deny-trump-even-gets-1237-delegates/

Almost too close to call, FiveThirtyEight have Trump running at 91% of target needed for nomination, which suggests he may fail. However, with so many winner take all states coming up, Trump's lead translates into a lot of delegates if it holds. He needs to lose about 3-4 states depending on size, and it seems unlikely based on polls.

Upgrading (qualitatively) based on Trump's polling in California, which is meaningfully stronger than last time I checked. Most recent 538 forecast showed a spike up for T. Will refine math based on results of 4/26 primaries.

http://www.reuters.com/article/uk-usa-election-republicans-idUSKCN0XM076
Larry and Curly have struck a deal.  Not a very good deal, and too late anyway.  Hair Boy in one.

I probably should have factored this permutation in but I didn't (https://www.johnkasich.com/blog-posts/kasich-campaign-statement-upcoming-primaries/). It should be enough to give Indiana to Cruz (next few polls will be key), but shouldn't affect Oregon or New Mexico as they are both proportional (may allow Kasich to stay in race longer too, and maybe win more states) so going back to previous forecasts. Sorry @dowser. H/T to @clinton for the pointing out The Guardian article.

Updating my forecast for latest Indiana and California polls. I have DT now on 36% to get 1237+ delegates, and 72% 1195+ delegates. I initially had Cruz winning Indiana on demographics but polls seem to suggest otherwise.

Really a question about whether Trump will hit the delegate target, which seems increasingly unlikely even though he very likely will get the most delegates. Trump would need 53.4% to get of remaining delegates. Seems unlikely as he's currently polling ~40% in the polls. New Jersey is winner takes all (51 delegates). But that probably is not enough to do it.
Latest reports suggest that the chance of a contested convention have stopped growing. Looks like he might get the nomination even if he doesn't have ebough pledged delegates.
Moving up 10. Looks like he will get a chunk of the PA uncommitted delegates, and a handful from Rubio supporters.
If Trump Get to within 20-30 Delegates the party will fall into line behind him. If he is 80-100 he will be beaten. I predict he will get 1200+.

Good article here that gives Trump a 75% of getting to 1237, I am still not there on that concept, but I am raising my forecast from 2 in 5 to 3 in 5. I am not sure the  study takes into account how some of the swing states award delegates by house districts, so counts may be different (Favoring Cruz) since Trump does not seem to understand the delegate process.
Donald has regained his stride, but his path to a first ballot victory is narrow. Indiana looks like the swing state here, though he could win it with a landslide in California as well.

Obviously, if there is a win first ballot, it will be Trump.  Thus, the question, will trump win first ballot?  As per 538, Trump is at about 95% of his target (i.e., down about 45 delegates), he is scheduled to win Connecticut, Maryland and Pennsylvania.  I haven't zoomed into the individual districts, but we will know more Tuesday. Trump is now slated to win California, and Cruz is dropping like a brick.  We haven't had a contested convention in a generation (40 years for Republicans).  There are around 200'ish unbound delegates. We can place political processes on a spectrum of transparency or formality, or even better, participant knowledge. And we can gradate that spectrum from full black (covert, informal, limited knowledge) to full white (overt, formal, full knowledge [including understanding]). Here are two examples of political processes that are both close to the middle of the spectrum, but on opposite sides of the formal/informal divide.
1) The rules of procedure. Formal.
2) Who sets the agenda? Informal. (You'd be surprised at how many board of director meeting agendas are set unilaterally by the CEO or corporate secretary!)
http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/republican-rules-clash-convention-222063

If Trump arrives at convention with a majority, it is probably but not necessarily all over.  Of the roughly four ways a second ballot could be prevented, one could beat him even if he has a majority going in:  the Credentials Committee. If you stack that committee properly, it can disallow the credentials of the Trump diehards on some pretext or other.  This would require a majority on the floor to support such an action, but remember that not all delegates pledged to Grump on first are his supporters, and nobody is pledged to vote a particular way on Credentials, Platform, or Rules questions. So the party regulars who are designated for Trump could vote to disqualify their ostensible teammates.  You’d need to have some alternates available, but not a big problem.

Trump is presently at 96% of the delegate target established by 538 (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/delegate-targets/). 
Using 538's tracker, he needs 40+ delegates in the following states:
- California (81/172). Winner-take-all, mostly at the congressional district level. There haven't been any polls since December; at that point the totals were 25% Cruz, 23% Trump and 1% Kasich. That would put Trump close to where he needs to be, though dropouts since (Rubio/Carson/Paul had combined for 28%) probably move more support to Cruz than Trump in my view. 
- Arizona (58/58). Winner-take-all. Last poll was in November and had it a three-way race between Trump, Carson and Rubio; I like Trump's chances. 
- New York (58/95) Proportional, mostly at a congressional district level, unless someone gets over 50%. Trump is at 45% in a recent poll, Kasich 18% and Kruz 11%. Even assuming Rubio's support largely goes to Kasich, there's a chance Trump tops 50% and takes everything.  
- Indiana (51/57). Winner-take-all, mostly at the congressional district level. No recent polling, but Trump won Michigan, Illinois and Kentucky. Kasich won Ohio to the East and was competitive in Michigan. Cruz was competitive in every bordering state other than Ohio. I think Trump takes most of the state, but 51 delegates is iffy. 
- New Jersey (51/51). Winner-take-all. In a February poll, Trump was at 33.3%, Rubio/Carson combined for 25.4%, with Cruz at 7.7% and Kasich at 4.3%. Nearly a lock for Trump, unless the dropout delegates universally go to his rivals. 
- Pennsylvania (40/71) 17 delegates are winner-take-all, the rest go in a "loophole" primary. The last RCP average had Trump at 29%, Rubio at 19%, Cruz at 17% and Kasich at 13%. Trumps chances here would seem to be good. 
Going through all that, I'm not sure my gut feel - which has Trump really close but not a lock to meet his delegate target changes much. It's close to 50/50 whether he crosses that magic threshold in my view; I'm tabbing him slightly under.

I am not sure that this question is different from whether any candidate will have a majority of delegates prior to the convention. The probability that a candidate other than Trump wins a majority of delegates seems vanishingly small. Trump appears to be on track to win a majority of delegates, but the Republican establishment seems to have shifted strategy towards conceding Trump a plurality if they are able to prevent a majority. Trump appears to be on track to win a considerable share of the ~750 delegates between today and March 15. The key question is whether the gap to the majority could be closed based solely on "hitting the board" in future primaries that allocate proportionally. In that case, it is difficult for me to see how an establishment-led push against Trump could deny him a majority. It appears that the upcoming contests most likely to go against Trump (which is not to say that they are likely to do so) are Ohio (66, winner take all), North Carolina (72, proportional) and Florida (99, winner take all). I will attempt to simplify by asserting: (a) if Trump is beaten in at least two of these states, the establishment will double down on a strategy to deny Trump a majority, and I will assume for now that it can succeed; (b) otherwise, Trump is highly likely to be able to obtain a majority. Based on 538's current forecast about the probability of a Trump win in these states (38%, 45% and 69% respectively) it looks like the probability that at least two go against Trump is ~50%. I bump the general probability that he obtains a majority to 60% because, well, he's winning so far, and my simplifications generally skew against him winning a majority.

Trump's performance on Super Tuesday was less dominant than I expected, and it leaves the door open for a (still unlikely but certainly not impossible) contested convention. Here's one take on how it might go: "Winning a majority of delegates doesn’t seem to be something [the Marco Rubio campaign] expects to do, especially after another ho-hum night on Super Tuesday. The goal now is to deny Trump from reaching an outright majority of delegates and then oust him after the first ballot at the convention. This isn’t just the backup plan anymore; it is the plan. This means that it might be better for all of the non–Donald Trump candidates to stay in the race and pick off potential wins from Trump here and there"[1]. Maybe. Like the author of this piece, I have my doubts about whether Rubio (and his establishment enablers - whoever they are) can pull this off. But the question is about whether Trump (or anyone else0 will win on a first ballot, and here we have some reason to think that even if Trump gets a plurality of delegates (as now seems probable), the convention might be a messier affair than usual.
